1765 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1766 // Helpers
1767 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1768 
1769 // Helper: Unicode defines
1770 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_INVALID 0xFFFD // Invalid Unicode code point (standard value).
1771 #ifdef IMGUI_USE_WCHAR32
1772 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX 0x10FFFF // Maximum Unicode code point supported by this build.
1773 #else
1774 #define IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX 0xFFFF // Maximum Unicode code point supported by this build.
1775 #endif
1776 
1777 // Helper: Execute a block of code at maximum once a frame. Convenient if you want to quickly create an UI within deep-nested code that runs multiple times every frame.
1778 // Usage: static ImGuiOnceUponAFrame oaf; if (oaf) ImGui::Text("This will be called only once per frame");
1779 struct ImGuiOnceUponAFrame
1780 {
1781  ImGuiOnceUponAFrame() { RefFrame = -1; }
1782  mutable int RefFrame;
1783  operator bool() const { int current_frame = ImGui::GetFrameCount(); if (RefFrame == current_frame) return false; RefFrame = current_frame; return true; }
1784 };
1785 
1786 // Helper: Parse and apply text filters. In format "aaaaa[,bbbb][,ccccc]"
1787 struct ImGuiTextFilter
1788 {
1789  IMGUI_API ImGuiTextFilter(const char* default_filter = "");
1790  IMGUI_API bool Draw(const char* label = "Filter (inc,-exc)", float width = 0.0f); // Helper calling InputText+Build
1791  IMGUI_API bool PassFilter(const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL) const;
1792  IMGUI_API void Build();
1793  void Clear() { InputBuf[0] = 0; Build(); }
1794  bool IsActive() const { return !Filters.empty(); }
1795 
1796  // [Internal]
1797  struct ImGuiTextRange
1798  {
1799  const char* b;
1800  const char* e;
1801 
1802  ImGuiTextRange() { b = e = NULL; }
1803  ImGuiTextRange(const char* _b, const char* _e) { b = _b; e = _e; }
1804  bool empty() const { return b == e; }
1805  IMGUI_API void split(char separator, ImVector<ImGuiTextRange>* out) const;
1806  };
1807  char InputBuf[256];
1808  ImVector<ImGuiTextRange>Filters;
1809  int CountGrep;
1810 };
1811 
1812 // Helper: Growable text buffer for logging/accumulating text
1813 // (this could be called 'ImGuiTextBuilder' / 'ImGuiStringBuilder')
1814 struct ImGuiTextBuffer
1815 {
1816  ImVector<char> Buf;
1817  IMGUI_API static char EmptyString[1];
1818 
1819  ImGuiTextBuffer() { }
1820  inline char operator[](int i) const { IM_ASSERT(Buf.Data != NULL); return Buf.Data[i]; }
1821  const char* begin() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.front() : EmptyString; }
1822  const char* end() const { return Buf.Data ? &Buf.back() : EmptyString; } // Buf is zero-terminated, so end() will point on the zero-terminator
1823  int size() const { return Buf.Size ? Buf.Size - 1 : 0; }
1824  bool empty() const { return Buf.Size <= 1; }
1825  void clear() { Buf.clear(); }
1826  void reserve(int capacity) { Buf.reserve(capacity); }
1827  const char* c_str() const { return Buf.Data ? Buf.Data : EmptyString; }
1828  IMGUI_API void append(const char* str, const char* str_end = NULL);
1829  IMGUI_API void appendf(const char* fmt, ...) IM_FMTARGS(2);
1830  IMGUI_API void appendfv(const char* fmt, va_list args) IM_FMTLIST(2);
1831 };
1832 
1833 // Helper: Key->Value storage
1834 // Typically you don't have to worry about this since a storage is held within each Window.
1835 // We use it to e.g. store collapse state for a tree (Int 0/1)
1836 // This is optimized for efficient lookup (dichotomy into a contiguous buffer) and rare insertion (typically tied to user interactions aka max once a frame)
1837 // You can use it as custom user storage for temporary values. Declare your own storage if, for example:
1838 // - You want to manipulate the open/close state of a particular sub-tree in your interface (tree node uses Int 0/1 to store their state).
1839 // - You want to store custom debug data easily without adding or editing structures in your code (probably not efficient, but convenient)
1840 // Types are NOT stored, so it is up to you to make sure your Key don't collide with different types.
1841 struct ImGuiStorage
1842 {
1843  // [Internal]
1844  struct ImGuiStoragePair
1845  {
1846  ImGuiID key;
1847  union { int val_i; float val_f; void* val_p; };
1848  ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, int _val_i) { key = _key; val_i = _val_i; }
1849  ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, float _val_f) { key = _key; val_f = _val_f; }
1850  ImGuiStoragePair(ImGuiID _key, void* _val_p) { key = _key; val_p = _val_p; }
1851  };
1852 
1853  ImVector<ImGuiStoragePair> Data;
1854 
1855  // - Get***() functions find pair, never add/allocate. Pairs are sorted so a query is O(log N)
1856  // - Set***() functions find pair, insertion on demand if missing.
1857  // - Sorted insertion is costly, paid once. A typical frame shouldn't need to insert any new pair.
1858  void Clear() { Data.clear(); }
1859  IMGUI_API int GetInt(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0) const;
1860  IMGUI_API void SetInt(ImGuiID key, int val);
1861  IMGUI_API bool GetBool(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false) const;
1862  IMGUI_API void SetBool(ImGuiID key, bool val);
1863  IMGUI_API float GetFloat(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f) const;
1864  IMGUI_API void SetFloat(ImGuiID key, float val);
1865  IMGUI_API void* GetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key) const; // default_val is NULL
1866  IMGUI_API void SetVoidPtr(ImGuiID key, void* val);
1867 
1868  // - Get***Ref() functions finds pair, insert on demand if missing, return pointer. Useful if you intend to do Get+Set.
1869  // - References are only valid until a new value is added to the storage. Calling a Set***() function or a Get***Ref() function invalidates the pointer.
1870  // - A typical use case where this is convenient for quick hacking (e.g. add storage during a live Edit&Continue session if you can't modify existing struct)
1871  // float* pvar = ImGui::GetFloatRef(key); ImGui::SliderFloat("var", pvar, 0, 100.0f); some_var += *pvar;
1872  IMGUI_API int* GetIntRef(ImGuiID key, int default_val = 0);
1873  IMGUI_API bool* GetBoolRef(ImGuiID key, bool default_val = false);
1874  IMGUI_API float* GetFloatRef(ImGuiID key, float default_val = 0.0f);
1875  IMGUI_API void** GetVoidPtrRef(ImGuiID key, void* default_val = NULL);
1876 
1877  // Use on your own storage if you know only integer are being stored (open/close all tree nodes)
1878  IMGUI_API void SetAllInt(int val);
1879 
1880  // For quicker full rebuild of a storage (instead of an incremental one), you may add all your contents and then sort once.
1881  IMGUI_API void BuildSortByKey();
1882 };
1883 
1884 // Helper: Manually clip large list of items.
1885 // If you are submitting lots of evenly spaced items and you have a random access to the list, you can perform coarse clipping based on visibility to save yourself from processing those items at all.
1886 // The clipper calculates the range of visible items and advance the cursor to compensate for the non-visible items we have skipped.
1887 // ImGui already clip items based on their bounds but it needs to measure text size to do so. Coarse clipping before submission makes this cost and your own data fetching/submission cost null.
1888 // Usage:
1889 // ImGuiListClipper clipper(1000); // we have 1000 elements, evenly spaced.
1890 // while (clipper.Step())
1891 // for (int i = clipper.DisplayStart; i < clipper.DisplayEnd; i++)
1892 // ImGui::Text("line number %d", i);
1893 // - Step 0: the clipper let you process the first element, regardless of it being visible or not, so we can measure the element height (step skipped if we passed a known height as second arg to constructor).
1894 // - Step 1: the clipper infer height from first element, calculate the actual range of elements to display, and position the cursor before the first element.
1895 // - (Step 2: dummy step only required if an explicit items_height was passed to constructor or Begin() and user call Step(). Does nothing and switch to Step 3.)
1896 // - Step 3: the clipper validate that we have reached the expected Y position (corresponding to element DisplayEnd), advance the cursor to the end of the list and then returns 'false' to end the loop.
1897 struct ImGuiListClipper
1898 {
1899  int DisplayStart, DisplayEnd;
1900  int ItemsCount;
1901 
1902  // [Internal]
1903  int StepNo;
1904  float ItemsHeight;
1905  float StartPosY;
1906 
1907  // items_count: Use -1 to ignore (you can call Begin later). Use INT_MAX if you don't know how many items you have (in which case the cursor won't be advanced in the final step).
1908  // items_height: Use -1.0f to be calculated automatically on first step. Otherwise pass in the distance between your items, typically GetTextLineHeightWithSpacing() or GetFrameHeightWithSpacing().
1909  // If you don't specify an items_height, you NEED to call Step(). If you specify items_height you may call the old Begin()/End() api directly, but prefer calling Step().
1910  ImGuiListClipper(int items_count = -1, float items_height = -1.0f) { Begin(items_count, items_height); } // NB: Begin() initialize every fields (as we allow user to call Begin/End multiple times on a same instance if they want).
1911  ~ImGuiListClipper() { IM_ASSERT(ItemsCount == -1); } // Assert if user forgot to call End() or Step() until false.
1912 
1913  IMGUI_API bool Step(); // Call until it returns false. The DisplayStart/DisplayEnd fields will be set and you can process/draw those items.
1914  IMGUI_API void Begin(int items_count, float items_height = -1.0f); // Automatically called by constructor if you passed 'items_count' or by Step() in Step 1.
1915  IMGUI_API void End(); // Automatically called on the last call of Step() that returns false.
1916 };
1917 
1918 // Helpers macros to generate 32-bit encoded colors
1919 #ifdef IMGUI_USE_BGRA_PACKED_COLOR
1920 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 16
1921 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
1922 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 0
1923 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
1924 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
1925 #else
1926 #define IM_COL32_R_SHIFT 0
1927 #define IM_COL32_G_SHIFT 8
1928 #define IM_COL32_B_SHIFT 16
1929 #define IM_COL32_A_SHIFT 24
1930 #define IM_COL32_A_MASK 0xFF000000
1931 #endif
1932 #define IM_COL32(R,G,B,A) (((ImU32)(A)<<IM_COL32_A_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(B)<<IM_COL32_B_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(G)<<IM_COL32_G_SHIFT) | ((ImU32)(R)<<IM_COL32_R_SHIFT))
1933 #define IM_COL32_WHITE IM_COL32(255,255,255,255) // Opaque white = 0xFFFFFFFF
1934 #define IM_COL32_BLACK IM_COL32(0,0,0,255) // Opaque black
1935 #define IM_COL32_BLACK_TRANS IM_COL32(0,0,0,0) // Transparent black = 0x00000000
1936 
1937 // Helper: ImColor() implicitly converts colors to either ImU32 (packed 4x1 byte) or ImVec4 (4x1 float)
1938 // Prefer using IM_COL32() macros if you want a guaranteed compile-time ImU32 for usage with ImDrawList API.
1939 // **Avoid storing ImColor! Store either u32 of ImVec4. This is not a full-featured color class. MAY OBSOLETE.
1940 // **None of the ImGui API are using ImColor directly but you can use it as a convenience to pass colors in either ImU32 or ImVec4 formats. Explicitly cast to ImU32 or ImVec4 if needed.
1941 struct ImColor
1942 {
1943  ImVec4 Value;
1944 
1945  ImColor() { Value.x = Value.y = Value.z = Value.w = 0.0f; }
1946  ImColor(int r, int g, int b, int a = 255) { float sc = 1.0f/255.0f; Value.x = (float)r * sc; Value.y = (float)g * sc; Value.z = (float)b * sc; Value.w = (float)a * sc; }
1947  ImColor(ImU32 rgba) { float sc = 1.0f/255.0f; Value.x = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_R_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.y = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_G_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.z = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_B_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; Value.w = (float)((rgba>>IM_COL32_A_SHIFT)&0xFF) * sc; }
1948  ImColor(float r, float g, float b, float a = 1.0f) { Value.x = r; Value.y = g; Value.z = b; Value.w = a; }
1949  ImColor(const ImVec4& col) { Value = col; }
1950  inline operator ImU32() const { return ImGui::ColorConvertFloat4ToU32(Value); }
1951  inline operator ImVec4() const { return Value; }
1952 
1953  // FIXME-OBSOLETE: May need to obsolete/cleanup those helpers.
1954  inline void SetHSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f){ ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, Value.x, Value.y, Value.z); Value.w = a; }
1955  static ImColor HSV(float h, float s, float v, float a = 1.0f) { float r,g,b; ImGui::ColorConvertHSVtoRGB(h, s, v, r, g, b); return ImColor(r,g,b,a); }
1956 };
1957 
1958 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1959 // Draw List API (ImDrawCmd, ImDrawIdx, ImDrawVert, ImDrawChannel, ImDrawListSplitter, ImDrawListFlags, ImDrawList, ImDrawData)
1960 // Hold a series of drawing commands. The user provides a renderer for ImDrawData which essentially contains an array of ImDrawList.
1961 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
1962 
1963 // ImDrawCallback: Draw callbacks for advanced uses [configurable type: override in imconfig.h]
1964 // NB: You most likely do NOT need to use draw callbacks just to create your own widget or customized UI rendering,
1965 // you can poke into the draw list for that! Draw callback may be useful for example to:
1966 // A) Change your GPU render state,
1967 // B) render a complex 3D scene inside a UI element without an intermediate texture/render target, etc.
1968 // The expected behavior from your rendering function is 'if (cmd.UserCallback != NULL) { cmd.UserCallback(parent_list, cmd); } else { RenderTriangles() }'
1969 // If you want to override the signature of ImDrawCallback, you can simply use e.g. '#define ImDrawCallback MyDrawCallback' (in imconfig.h) + update rendering back-end accordingly.
1970 #ifndef ImDrawCallback
1971 typedef void (*ImDrawCallback)(const ImDrawList* parent_list, const ImDrawCmd* cmd);
1972 #endif
1973 
1974 // Special Draw callback value to request renderer back-end to reset the graphics/render state.
1975 // The renderer back-end needs to handle this special value, otherwise it will crash trying to call a function at this address.
1976 // This is useful for example if you submitted callbacks which you know have altered the render state and you want it to be restored.
1977 // It is not done by default because they are many perfectly useful way of altering render state for imgui contents (e.g. changing shader/blending settings before an Image call).
1978 #define ImDrawCallback_ResetRenderState (ImDrawCallback)(-1)
1979 
1980 // Typically, 1 command = 1 GPU draw call (unless command is a callback)
1981 // Pre 1.71 back-ends will typically ignore the VtxOffset/IdxOffset fields. When 'io.BackendFlags & ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset'
1982 // is enabled, those fields allow us to render meshes larger than 64K vertices while keeping 16-bit indices.
1983 struct ImDrawCmd
1984 {
1985  unsigned int ElemCount; // Number of indices (multiple of 3) to be rendered as triangles. Vertices are stored in the callee ImDrawList's vtx_buffer[] array, indices in idx_buffer[].
1986  ImVec4 ClipRect; // Clipping rectangle (x1, y1, x2, y2). Subtract ImDrawData->DisplayPos to get clipping rectangle in "viewport" coordinates
1987  ImTextureID TextureId; // User-provided texture ID. Set by user in ImfontAtlas::SetTexID() for fonts or passed to Image*() functions. Ignore if never using images or multiple fonts atlas.
1988  unsigned int VtxOffset; // Start offset in vertex buffer. Pre-1.71 or without ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset: always 0. With ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset: may be >0 to support meshes larger than 64K vertices with 16-bit indices.
1989  unsigned int IdxOffset; // Start offset in index buffer. Always equal to sum of ElemCount drawn so far.
1990  ImDrawCallback UserCallback; // If != NULL, call the function instead of rendering the vertices. clip_rect and texture_id will be set normally.
1991  void* UserCallbackData; // The draw callback code can access this.
1992 
1993  ImDrawCmd() { ElemCount = 0; TextureId = (ImTextureID)NULL; VtxOffset = IdxOffset = 0; UserCallback = NULL; UserCallbackData = NULL; }
1994 };
1995 
1996 // Vertex index, default to 16-bit
1997 // To allow large meshes with 16-bit indices: set 'io.BackendFlags |= ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' and handle ImDrawCmd::VtxOffset in the renderer back-end (recommended).
1998 // To use 32-bit indices: override with '#define ImDrawIdx unsigned int' in imconfig.h.
1999 #ifndef ImDrawIdx
2000 typedef unsigned short ImDrawIdx;
2001 #endif
2002 
2003 // Vertex layout
2004 #ifndef IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT
2005 struct ImDrawVert
2006 {
2007  ImVec2 pos;
2008  ImVec2 uv;
2009  ImU32 col;
2010 };
2011 #else
2012 // You can override the vertex format layout by defining IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT in imconfig.h
2013 // The code expect ImVec2 pos (8 bytes), ImVec2 uv (8 bytes), ImU32 col (4 bytes), but you can re-order them or add other fields as needed to simplify integration in your engine.
2014 // The type has to be described within the macro (you can either declare the struct or use a typedef). This is because ImVec2/ImU32 are likely not declared a the time you'd want to set your type up.
2015 // NOTE: IMGUI DOESN'T CLEAR THE STRUCTURE AND DOESN'T CALL A CONSTRUCTOR SO ANY CUSTOM FIELD WILL BE UNINITIALIZED. IF YOU ADD EXTRA FIELDS (SUCH AS A 'Z' COORDINATES) YOU WILL NEED TO CLEAR THEM DURING RENDER OR TO IGNORE THEM.
2016 IMGUI_OVERRIDE_DRAWVERT_STRUCT_LAYOUT;
2017 #endif
2018 
2019 // For use by ImDrawListSplitter.
2020 struct ImDrawChannel
2021 {
2022  ImVector<ImDrawCmd> _CmdBuffer;
2023  ImVector<ImDrawIdx> _IdxBuffer;
2024 };
2025 
2026 // Split/Merge functions are used to split the draw list into different layers which can be drawn into out of order.
2027 // This is used by the Columns api, so items of each column can be batched together in a same draw call.
2028 struct ImDrawListSplitter
2029 {
2030  int _Current; // Current channel number (0)
2031  int _Count; // Number of active channels (1+)
2032  ImVector<ImDrawChannel> _Channels; // Draw channels (not resized down so _Count might be < Channels.Size)
2033 
2034  inline ImDrawListSplitter() { Clear(); }
2035  inline ~ImDrawListSplitter() { ClearFreeMemory(); }
2036  inline void Clear() { _Current = 0; _Count = 1; } // Do not clear Channels[] so our allocations are reused next frame
2037  IMGUI_API void ClearFreeMemory();
2038  IMGUI_API void Split(ImDrawList* draw_list, int count);
2039  IMGUI_API void Merge(ImDrawList* draw_list);
2040  IMGUI_API void SetCurrentChannel(ImDrawList* draw_list, int channel_idx);
2041 };
2042 
2043 enum ImDrawCornerFlags_
2044 {
2045  ImDrawCornerFlags_None = 0,
2046  ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft = 1 << 0, // 0x1
2047  ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight = 1 << 1, // 0x2
2048  ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft = 1 << 2, // 0x4
2049  ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight = 1 << 3, // 0x8
2050  ImDrawCornerFlags_Top = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight, // 0x3
2051  ImDrawCornerFlags_Bot = ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight, // 0xC
2052  ImDrawCornerFlags_Left = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopLeft | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotLeft, // 0x5
2053  ImDrawCornerFlags_Right = ImDrawCornerFlags_TopRight | ImDrawCornerFlags_BotRight, // 0xA
2054  ImDrawCornerFlags_All = 0xF // In your function calls you may use ~0 (= all bits sets) instead of ImDrawCornerFlags_All, as a convenience
2055 };
2056 
2057 enum ImDrawListFlags_
2058 {
2059  ImDrawListFlags_None = 0,
2060  ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedLines = 1 << 0, // Lines are anti-aliased (*2 the number of triangles for 1.0f wide line, otherwise *3 the number of triangles)
2061  ImDrawListFlags_AntiAliasedFill = 1 << 1, // Filled shapes have anti-aliased edges (*2 the number of vertices)
2062  ImDrawListFlags_AllowVtxOffset = 1 << 2 // Can emit 'VtxOffset > 0' to allow large meshes. Set when 'ImGuiBackendFlags_RendererHasVtxOffset' is enabled.
2063 };
2064 
2065 // Draw command list
2066 // This is the low-level list of polygons that ImGui:: functions are filling. At the end of the frame,
2067 // all command lists are passed to your ImGuiIO::RenderDrawListFn function for rendering.
2068 // Each dear imgui window contains its own ImDrawList. You can use ImGui::GetWindowDrawList() to
2069 // access the current window draw list and draw custom primitives.
2070 // You can interleave normal ImGui:: calls and adding primitives to the current draw list.
2071 // All positions are generally in pixel coordinates (generally top-left at 0,0, bottom-right at io.DisplaySize, unless multiple viewports are used), but you are totally free to apply whatever transformation matrix to want to the data (if you apply such transformation you'll want to apply it to ClipRect as well)
2072 // Important: Primitives are always added to the list and not culled (culling is done at higher-level by ImGui:: functions), if you use this API a lot consider coarse culling your drawn objects.
2073 struct ImDrawList
2074 {
2075  // This is what you have to render
2076  ImVector<ImDrawCmd> CmdBuffer; // Draw commands. Typically 1 command = 1 GPU draw call, unless the command is a callback.
2077  ImVector<ImDrawIdx> IdxBuffer; // Index buffer. Each command consume ImDrawCmd::ElemCount of those
2078  ImVector<ImDrawVert> VtxBuffer; // Vertex buffer.
2079  ImDrawListFlags Flags; // Flags, you may poke into these to adjust anti-aliasing settings per-primitive.
2080 
2081  // [Internal, used while building lists]
2082  const ImDrawListSharedData* _Data; // Pointer to shared draw data (you can use ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() to get the one from current ImGui context)
2083  const char* _OwnerName; // Pointer to owner window's name for debugging
2084  unsigned int _VtxCurrentOffset; // [Internal] Always 0 unless 'Flags & ImDrawListFlags_AllowVtxOffset'.
2085  unsigned int _VtxCurrentIdx; // [Internal] Generally == VtxBuffer.Size unless we are past 64K vertices, in which case this gets reset to 0.
2086  ImDrawVert* _VtxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within VtxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
2087  ImDrawIdx* _IdxWritePtr; // [Internal] point within IdxBuffer.Data after each add command (to avoid using the ImVector<> operators too much)
2088  ImVector<ImVec4> _ClipRectStack; // [Internal]
2089  ImVector<ImTextureID> _TextureIdStack; // [Internal]
2090  ImVector<ImVec2> _Path; // [Internal] current path building
2091  ImDrawListSplitter _Splitter; // [Internal] for channels api
2092 
2093  // If you want to create ImDrawList instances, pass them ImGui::GetDrawListSharedData() or create and use your own ImDrawListSharedData (so you can use ImDrawList without ImGui)
2094  ImDrawList(const ImDrawListSharedData* shared_data) { _Data = shared_data; _OwnerName = NULL; Clear(); }
2095  ~ImDrawList() { ClearFreeMemory(); }
2096  IMGUI_API void PushClipRect(ImVec2 clip_rect_min, ImVec2 clip_rect_max, bool intersect_with_current_clip_rect = false); // Render-level scissoring. This is passed down to your render function but not used for CPU-side coarse clipping. Prefer using higher-level ImGui::PushClipRect() to affect logic (hit-testing and widget culling)
2097  IMGUI_API void PushClipRectFullScreen();
2098  IMGUI_API void PopClipRect();
2099  IMGUI_API void PushTextureID(ImTextureID texture_id);
2100  IMGUI_API void PopTextureID();
2101  inline ImVec2 GetClipRectMin() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.x, cr.y); }
2102  inline ImVec2 GetClipRectMax() const { const ImVec4& cr = _ClipRectStack.back(); return ImVec2(cr.z, cr.w); }
2103 
2104  // Primitives
2105  // - For rectangular primitives, "p_min" and "p_max" represent the upper-left and lower-right corners.
2106  // - For circle primitives, use "num_segments == 0" to automatically calculate tessellation (preferred).
2107  // In future versions we will use textures to provide cheaper and higher-quality circles.
2108  // Use AddNgon() and AddNgonFilled() functions if you need to guaranteed a specific number of sides.
2109  IMGUI_API void AddLine(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
2110  IMGUI_API void AddRect(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawCornerFlags rounding_corners = ImDrawCornerFlags_All, float thickness = 1.0f); // a: upper-left, b: lower-right (== upper-left + size), rounding_corners_flags: 4 bits corresponding to which corner to round
2111  IMGUI_API void AddRectFilled(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawCornerFlags rounding_corners = ImDrawCornerFlags_All); // a: upper-left, b: lower-right (== upper-left + size)
2112  IMGUI_API void AddRectFilledMultiColor(const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, ImU32 col_upr_left, ImU32 col_upr_right, ImU32 col_bot_right, ImU32 col_bot_left);
2113  IMGUI_API void AddQuad(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
2114  IMGUI_API void AddQuadFilled(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col);
2115  IMGUI_API void AddTriangle(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, ImU32 col, float thickness = 1.0f);
2116  IMGUI_API void AddTriangleFilled(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, ImU32 col);
2117  IMGUI_API void AddCircle(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments = 12, float thickness = 1.0f);
2118  IMGUI_API void AddCircleFilled(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments = 12);
2119  IMGUI_API void AddNgon(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments, float thickness = 1.0f);
2120  IMGUI_API void AddNgonFilled(const ImVec2& center, float radius, ImU32 col, int num_segments);
2121  IMGUI_API void AddText(const ImVec2& pos, ImU32 col, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL);
2122  IMGUI_API void AddText(const ImFont* font, float font_size, const ImVec2& pos, ImU32 col, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL, float wrap_width = 0.0f, const ImVec4* cpu_fine_clip_rect = NULL);
2123  IMGUI_API void AddPolyline(const ImVec2* points, int num_points, ImU32 col, bool closed, float thickness);
2124  IMGUI_API void AddConvexPolyFilled(const ImVec2* points, int num_points, ImU32 col); // Note: Anti-aliased filling requires points to be in clockwise order.
2125  IMGUI_API void AddBezierCurve(const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, ImU32 col, float thickness, int num_segments = 0);
2126 
2127  // Image primitives
2128  // - Read FAQ to understand what ImTextureID is.
2129  // - "p_min" and "p_max" represent the upper-left and lower-right corners of the rectangle.
2130  // - "uv_min" and "uv_max" represent the normalized texture coordinates to use for those corners. Using (0,0)->(1,1) texture coordinates will generally display the entire texture.
2131  IMGUI_API void AddImage(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, const ImVec2& uv_min = ImVec2(0, 0), const ImVec2& uv_max = ImVec2(1, 1), ImU32 col = IM_COL32_WHITE);
2132  IMGUI_API void AddImageQuad(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p1, const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, const ImVec2& uv1 = ImVec2(0, 0), const ImVec2& uv2 = ImVec2(1, 0), const ImVec2& uv3 = ImVec2(1, 1), const ImVec2& uv4 = ImVec2(0, 1), ImU32 col = IM_COL32_WHITE);
2133  IMGUI_API void AddImageRounded(ImTextureID user_texture_id, const ImVec2& p_min, const ImVec2& p_max, const ImVec2& uv_min, const ImVec2& uv_max, ImU32 col, float rounding, ImDrawCornerFlags rounding_corners = ImDrawCornerFlags_All);
2134 
2135  // Stateful path API, add points then finish with PathFillConvex() or PathStroke()
2136  inline void PathClear() { _Path.Size = 0; }
2137  inline void PathLineTo(const ImVec2& pos) { _Path.push_back(pos); }
2138  inline void PathLineToMergeDuplicate(const ImVec2& pos) { if (_Path.Size == 0 || memcmp(&_Path.Data[_Path.Size-1], &pos, 8) != 0) _Path.push_back(pos); }
2139  inline void PathFillConvex(ImU32 col) { AddConvexPolyFilled(_Path.Data, _Path.Size, col); _Path.Size = 0; } // Note: Anti-aliased filling requires points to be in clockwise order.
2140  inline void PathStroke(ImU32 col, bool closed, float thickness = 1.0f) { AddPolyline(_Path.Data, _Path.Size, col, closed, thickness); _Path.Size = 0; }
2141  IMGUI_API void PathArcTo(const ImVec2& center, float radius, float a_min, float a_max, int num_segments = 10);
2142  IMGUI_API void PathArcToFast(const ImVec2& center, float radius, int a_min_of_12, int a_max_of_12); // Use precomputed angles for a 12 steps circle
2143  IMGUI_API void PathBezierCurveTo(const ImVec2& p2, const ImVec2& p3, const ImVec2& p4, int num_segments = 0);
2144  IMGUI_API void PathRect(const ImVec2& rect_min, const ImVec2& rect_max, float rounding = 0.0f, ImDrawCornerFlags rounding_corners = ImDrawCornerFlags_All);
2145 
2146  // Advanced
2147  IMGUI_API void AddCallback(ImDrawCallback callback, void* callback_data); // Your rendering function must check for 'UserCallback' in ImDrawCmd and call the function instead of rendering triangles.
2148  IMGUI_API void AddDrawCmd(); // This is useful if you need to forcefully create a new draw call (to allow for dependent rendering / blending). Otherwise primitives are merged into the same draw-call as much as possible
2149  IMGUI_API ImDrawList* CloneOutput() const; // Create a clone of the CmdBuffer/IdxBuffer/VtxBuffer.
2150 
2151  // Advanced: Channels
2152  // - Use to split render into layers. By switching channels to can render out-of-order (e.g. submit FG primitives before BG primitives)
2153  // - Use to minimize draw calls (e.g. if going back-and-forth between multiple clipping rectangles, prefer to append into separate channels then merge at the end)
2154  // - FIXME-OBSOLETE: This API shouldn't have been in ImDrawList in the first place!
2155  // Prefer using your own persistent copy of ImDrawListSplitter as you can stack them.
2156  // Using the ImDrawList::ChannelsXXXX you cannot stack a split over another.
2157  inline void ChannelsSplit(int count) { _Splitter.Split(this, count); }
2158  inline void ChannelsMerge() { _Splitter.Merge(this); }
2159  inline void ChannelsSetCurrent(int n) { _Splitter.SetCurrentChannel(this, n); }
2160 
2161  // Internal helpers
2162  // NB: all primitives needs to be reserved via PrimReserve() beforehand!
2163  IMGUI_API void Clear();
2164  IMGUI_API void ClearFreeMemory();
2165  IMGUI_API void PrimReserve(int idx_count, int vtx_count);
2166  IMGUI_API void PrimUnreserve(int idx_count, int vtx_count);
2167  IMGUI_API void PrimRect(const ImVec2& a, const ImVec2& b, ImU32 col); // Axis aligned rectangle (composed of two triangles)
2168  IMGUI_API void PrimRectUV(const ImVec2& a, const ImVec2& b, const ImVec2& uv_a, const ImVec2& uv_b, ImU32 col);
2169  IMGUI_API void PrimQuadUV(const ImVec2& a, const ImVec2& b, const ImVec2& c, const ImVec2& d, const ImVec2& uv_a, const ImVec2& uv_b, const ImVec2& uv_c, const ImVec2& uv_d, ImU32 col);
2170  inline void PrimWriteVtx(const ImVec2& pos, const ImVec2& uv, ImU32 col){ _VtxWritePtr->pos = pos; _VtxWritePtr->uv = uv; _VtxWritePtr->col = col; _VtxWritePtr++; _VtxCurrentIdx++; }
2171  inline void PrimWriteIdx(ImDrawIdx idx) { *_IdxWritePtr = idx; _IdxWritePtr++; }
2172  inline void PrimVtx(const ImVec2& pos, const ImVec2& uv, ImU32 col) { PrimWriteIdx((ImDrawIdx)_VtxCurrentIdx); PrimWriteVtx(pos, uv, col); }
2173  IMGUI_API void UpdateClipRect();
2174  IMGUI_API void UpdateTextureID();
2175 };
2176 
2177 // All draw data to render a Dear ImGui frame
2178 // (NB: the style and the naming convention here is a little inconsistent, we currently preserve them for backward compatibility purpose,
2179 // as this is one of the oldest structure exposed by the library! Basically, ImDrawList == CmdList)
2180 struct ImDrawData
2181 {
2182  bool Valid; // Only valid after Render() is called and before the next NewFrame() is called.
2183  ImDrawList** CmdLists; // Array of ImDrawList* to render. The ImDrawList are owned by ImGuiContext and only pointed to from here.
2184  int CmdListsCount; // Number of ImDrawList* to render
2185  int TotalIdxCount; // For convenience, sum of all ImDrawList's IdxBuffer.Size
2186  int TotalVtxCount; // For convenience, sum of all ImDrawList's VtxBuffer.Size
2187  ImVec2 DisplayPos; // Upper-left position of the viewport to render (== upper-left of the orthogonal projection matrix to use)
2188  ImVec2 DisplaySize; // Size of the viewport to render (== io.DisplaySize for the main viewport) (DisplayPos + DisplaySize == lower-right of the orthogonal projection matrix to use)
2189  ImVec2 FramebufferScale; // Amount of pixels for each unit of DisplaySize. Based on io.DisplayFramebufferScale. Generally (1,1) on normal display, (2,2) on OSX with Retina display.
2190  ImGuiViewport* OwnerViewport; // Viewport carrying the ImDrawData instance, might be of use to the renderer (generally not).
2191 
2192  // Functions
2193  ImDrawData() { Valid = false; Clear(); }
2194  ~ImDrawData() { Clear(); }
2195  void Clear() { Valid = false; CmdLists = NULL; CmdListsCount = TotalVtxCount = TotalIdxCount = 0; DisplayPos = DisplaySize = FramebufferScale = ImVec2(0.f, 0.f); OwnerViewport = NULL; } // The ImDrawList are owned by ImGuiContext!
2196  IMGUI_API void DeIndexAllBuffers(); // Helper to convert all buffers from indexed to non-indexed, in case you cannot render indexed. Note: this is slow and most likely a waste of resources. Always prefer indexed rendering!
2197  IMGUI_API void ScaleClipRects(const ImVec2& fb_scale); // Helper to scale the ClipRect field of each ImDrawCmd. Use if your final output buffer is at a different scale than Dear ImGui expects, or if there is a difference between your window resolution and framebuffer resolution.
2198 };
2199 
2200 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2201 // Font API (ImFontConfig, ImFontGlyph, ImFontAtlasFlags, ImFontAtlas, ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder, ImFont)
2202 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2203 
2204 struct ImFontConfig
2205 {
2206  void* FontData; // // TTF/OTF data
2207  int FontDataSize; // // TTF/OTF data size
2208  bool FontDataOwnedByAtlas; // true // TTF/OTF data ownership taken by the container ImFontAtlas (will delete memory itself).
2209  int FontNo; // 0 // Index of font within TTF/OTF file
2210  float SizePixels; // // Size in pixels for rasterizer (more or less maps to the resulting font height).
2211  int OversampleH; // 3 // Rasterize at higher quality for sub-pixel positioning. Read https://github.com/nothings/stb/blob/master/tests/oversample/README.md for details.
2212  int OversampleV; // 1 // Rasterize at higher quality for sub-pixel positioning. We don't use sub-pixel positions on the Y axis.
2213  bool PixelSnapH; // false // Align every glyph to pixel boundary. Useful e.g. if you are merging a non-pixel aligned font with the default font. If enabled, you can set OversampleH/V to 1.
2214  ImVec2 GlyphExtraSpacing; // 0, 0 // Extra spacing (in pixels) between glyphs. Only X axis is supported for now.
2215  ImVec2 GlyphOffset; // 0, 0 // Offset all glyphs from this font input.
2216  const ImWchar* GlyphRanges; // NULL // Pointer to a user-provided list of Unicode range (2 value per range, values are inclusive, zero-terminated list). THE ARRAY DATA NEEDS TO PERSIST AS LONG AS THE FONT IS ALIVE.
2217  float GlyphMinAdvanceX; // 0 // Minimum AdvanceX for glyphs, set Min to align font icons, set both Min/Max to enforce mono-space font
2218  float GlyphMaxAdvanceX; // FLT_MAX // Maximum AdvanceX for glyphs
2219  bool MergeMode; // false // Merge into previous ImFont, so you can combine multiple inputs font into one ImFont (e.g. ASCII font + icons + Japanese glyphs). You may want to use GlyphOffset.y when merge font of different heights.
2220  unsigned int RasterizerFlags; // 0x00 // Settings for custom font rasterizer (e.g. ImGuiFreeType). Leave as zero if you aren't using one.
2221  float RasterizerMultiply; // 1.0f // Brighten (>1.0f) or darken (<1.0f) font output. Brightening small fonts may be a good workaround to make them more readable.
2222  ImWchar EllipsisChar; // -1 // Explicitly specify unicode codepoint of ellipsis character. When fonts are being merged first specified ellipsis will be used.
2223 
2224  // [Internal]
2225  char Name[40]; // Name (strictly to ease debugging)
2226  ImFont* DstFont;
2227 
2228  IMGUI_API ImFontConfig();
2229 };
2230 
2231 // Hold rendering data for one glyph.
2232 // (Note: some language parsers may fail to convert the 31+1 bitfield members, in this case maybe drop store a single u32 or we can rework this)
2233 struct ImFontGlyph
2234 {
2235  unsigned int Codepoint : 31; // 0x0000..0xFFFF
2236  unsigned int Visible : 1; // Flag to allow early out when rendering
2237  float AdvanceX; // Distance to next character (= data from font + ImFontConfig::GlyphExtraSpacing.x baked in)
2238  float X0, Y0, X1, Y1; // Glyph corners
2239  float U0, V0, U1, V1; // Texture coordinates
2240 };
2241 
2242 // Helper to build glyph ranges from text/string data. Feed your application strings/characters to it then call BuildRanges().
2243 // This is essentially a tightly packed of vector of 64k booleans = 8KB storage.
2244 struct ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder
2245 {
2246  ImVector<ImU32> UsedChars; // Store 1-bit per Unicode code point (0=unused, 1=used)
2247 
2248  ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder() { Clear(); }
2249  inline void Clear() { int size_in_bytes = (IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX + 1) / 8; UsedChars.resize(size_in_bytes / (int)sizeof(ImU32)); memset(UsedChars.Data, 0, (size_t)size_in_bytes); }
2250  inline bool GetBit(size_t n) const { int off = (int)(n >> 5); ImU32 mask = 1u << (n & 31); return (UsedChars[off] & mask) != 0; } // Get bit n in the array
2251  inline void SetBit(size_t n) { int off = (int)(n >> 5); ImU32 mask = 1u << (n & 31); UsedChars[off] |= mask; } // Set bit n in the array
2252  inline void AddChar(ImWchar c) { SetBit(c); } // Add character
2253  IMGUI_API void AddText(const char* text, const char* text_end = NULL); // Add string (each character of the UTF-8 string are added)
2254  IMGUI_API void AddRanges(const ImWchar* ranges); // Add ranges, e.g. builder.AddRanges(ImFontAtlas::GetGlyphRangesDefault()) to force add all of ASCII/Latin+Ext
2255  IMGUI_API void BuildRanges(ImVector<ImWchar>* out_ranges); // Output new ranges
2256 };
2257 
2258 // See ImFontAtlas::AddCustomRectXXX functions.
2259 struct ImFontAtlasCustomRect
2260 {
2261  unsigned short Width, Height; // Input // Desired rectangle dimension
2262  unsigned short X, Y; // Output // Packed position in Atlas
2263  unsigned int GlyphID; // Input // For custom font glyphs only (ID < 0x110000)
2264  float GlyphAdvanceX; // Input // For custom font glyphs only: glyph xadvance
2265  ImVec2 GlyphOffset; // Input // For custom font glyphs only: glyph display offset
2266  ImFont* Font; // Input // For custom font glyphs only: target font
2267  ImFontAtlasCustomRect() { Width = Height = 0; X = Y = 0xFFFF; GlyphID = 0; GlyphAdvanceX = 0.0f; GlyphOffset = ImVec2(0,0); Font = NULL; }
2268  bool IsPacked() const { return X != 0xFFFF; }
2269 };
2270 
2271 enum ImFontAtlasFlags_
2272 {
2273  ImFontAtlasFlags_None = 0,
2274  ImFontAtlasFlags_NoPowerOfTwoHeight = 1 << 0, // Don't round the height to next power of two
2275  ImFontAtlasFlags_NoMouseCursors = 1 << 1 // Don't build software mouse cursors into the atlas
2276 };
2277 
2278 // Load and rasterize multiple TTF/OTF fonts into a same texture. The font atlas will build a single texture holding:
2279 // - One or more fonts.
2280 // - Custom graphics data needed to render the shapes needed by Dear ImGui.
2281 // - Mouse cursor shapes for software cursor rendering (unless setting 'Flags |= ImFontAtlasFlags_NoMouseCursors' in the font atlas).
2282 // It is the user-code responsibility to setup/build the atlas, then upload the pixel data into a texture accessible by your graphics api.
2283 // - Optionally, call any of the AddFont*** functions. If you don't call any, the default font embedded in the code will be loaded for you.
2284 // - Call GetTexDataAsAlpha8() or GetTexDataAsRGBA32() to build and retrieve pixels data.
2285 // - Upload the pixels data into a texture within your graphics system (see imgui_impl_xxxx.cpp examples)
2286 // - Call SetTexID(my_tex_id); and pass the pointer/identifier to your texture in a format natural to your graphics API.
2287 // This value will be passed back to you during rendering to identify the texture. Read FAQ entry about ImTextureID for more details.
2288 // Common pitfalls:
2289 // - If you pass a 'glyph_ranges' array to AddFont*** functions, you need to make sure that your array persist up until the
2290 // atlas is build (when calling GetTexData*** or Build()). We only copy the pointer, not the data.
2291 // - Important: By default, AddFontFromMemoryTTF() takes ownership of the data. Even though we are not writing to it, we will free the pointer on destruction.
2292 // You can set font_cfg->FontDataOwnedByAtlas=false to keep ownership of your data and it won't be freed,
2293 // - Even though many functions are suffixed with "TTF", OTF data is supported just as well.
2294 // - This is an old API and it is currently awkward for those and and various other reasons! We will address them in the future!
2295 struct ImFontAtlas
2296 {
2297  IMGUI_API ImFontAtlas();
2298  IMGUI_API ~ImFontAtlas();
2299  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFont(const ImFontConfig* font_cfg);
2300  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontDefault(const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL);
2301  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromFileTTF(const char* filename, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL);
2302  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryTTF(void* font_data, int font_size, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // Note: Transfer ownership of 'ttf_data' to ImFontAtlas! Will be deleted after destruction of the atlas. Set font_cfg->FontDataOwnedByAtlas=false to keep ownership of your data and it won't be freed.
2303  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryCompressedTTF(const void* compressed_font_data, int compressed_font_size, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // 'compressed_font_data' still owned by caller. Compress with binary_to_compressed_c.cpp.
2304  IMGUI_API ImFont* AddFontFromMemoryCompressedBase85TTF(const char* compressed_font_data_base85, float size_pixels, const ImFontConfig* font_cfg = NULL, const ImWchar* glyph_ranges = NULL); // 'compressed_font_data_base85' still owned by caller. Compress with binary_to_compressed_c.cpp with -base85 parameter.
2305  IMGUI_API void ClearInputData(); // Clear input data (all ImFontConfig structures including sizes, TTF data, glyph ranges, etc.) = all the data used to build the texture and fonts.
2306  IMGUI_API void ClearTexData(); // Clear output texture data (CPU side). Saves RAM once the texture has been copied to graphics memory.
2307  IMGUI_API void ClearFonts(); // Clear output font data (glyphs storage, UV coordinates).
2308  IMGUI_API void Clear(); // Clear all input and output.
2309 
2310  // Build atlas, retrieve pixel data.
2311  // User is in charge of copying the pixels into graphics memory (e.g. create a texture with your engine). Then store your texture handle with SetTexID().
2312  // The pitch is always = Width * BytesPerPixels (1 or 4)
2313  // Building in RGBA32 format is provided for convenience and compatibility, but note that unless you manually manipulate or copy color data into
2314  // the texture (e.g. when using the AddCustomRect*** api), then the RGB pixels emitted will always be white (~75% of memory/bandwidth waste.
2315  IMGUI_API bool Build(); // Build pixels data. This is called automatically for you by the GetTexData*** functions.
2316  IMGUI_API void GetTexDataAsAlpha8(unsigned char** out_pixels, int* out_width, int* out_height, int* out_bytes_per_pixel = NULL); // 1 byte per-pixel
2317  IMGUI_API void GetTexDataAsRGBA32(unsigned char** out_pixels, int* out_width, int* out_height, int* out_bytes_per_pixel = NULL); // 4 bytes-per-pixel
2318  bool IsBuilt() const { return Fonts.Size > 0 && (TexPixelsAlpha8 != NULL || TexPixelsRGBA32 != NULL); }
2319  void SetTexID(ImTextureID id) { TexID = id; }
2320 
2321  //-------------------------------------------
2322  // Glyph Ranges
2323  //-------------------------------------------
2324 
2325  // Helpers to retrieve list of common Unicode ranges (2 value per range, values are inclusive, zero-terminated list)
2326  // NB: Make sure that your string are UTF-8 and NOT in your local code page. In C++11, you can create UTF-8 string literal using the u8"Hello world" syntax. See FAQ for details.
2327  // NB: Consider using ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder to build glyph ranges from textual data.
2328  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesDefault(); // Basic Latin, Extended Latin
2329  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesKorean(); // Default + Korean characters
2330  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesJapanese(); // Default + Hiragana, Katakana, Half-Width, Selection of 1946 Ideographs
2331  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesChineseFull(); // Default + Half-Width + Japanese Hiragana/Katakana + full set of about 21000 CJK Unified Ideographs
2332  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesChineseSimplifiedCommon();// Default + Half-Width + Japanese Hiragana/Katakana + set of 2500 CJK Unified Ideographs for common simplified Chinese
2333  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesCyrillic(); // Default + about 400 Cyrillic characters
2334  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesThai(); // Default + Thai characters
2335  IMGUI_API const ImWchar* GetGlyphRangesVietnamese(); // Default + Vietnamese characters
2336 
2337  //-------------------------------------------
2338  // [BETA] Custom Rectangles/Glyphs API
2339  //-------------------------------------------
2340 
2341  // You can request arbitrary rectangles to be packed into the atlas, for your own purposes.
2342  // After calling Build(), you can query the rectangle position and render your pixels.
2343  // You can also request your rectangles to be mapped as font glyph (given a font + Unicode point),
2344  // so you can render e.g. custom colorful icons and use them as regular glyphs.
2345  // Read docs/FONTS.txt for more details about using colorful icons.
2346  // Note: this API may be redesigned later in order to support multi-monitor varying DPI settings.
2347  IMGUI_API int AddCustomRectRegular(int width, int height);
2348  IMGUI_API int AddCustomRectFontGlyph(ImFont* font, ImWchar id, int width, int height, float advance_x, const ImVec2& offset = ImVec2(0,0));
2349  const ImFontAtlasCustomRect*GetCustomRectByIndex(int index) const { if (index < 0) return NULL; return &CustomRects[index]; }
2350 
2351  // [Internal]
2352  IMGUI_API void CalcCustomRectUV(const ImFontAtlasCustomRect* rect, ImVec2* out_uv_min, ImVec2* out_uv_max) const;
2353  IMGUI_API bool GetMouseCursorTexData(ImGuiMouseCursor cursor, ImVec2* out_offset, ImVec2* out_size, ImVec2 out_uv_border[2], ImVec2 out_uv_fill[2]);
2354 
2355  //-------------------------------------------
2356  // Members
2357  //-------------------------------------------
2358 
2359  bool Locked; // Marked as Locked by ImGui::NewFrame() so attempt to modify the atlas will assert.
2360  ImFontAtlasFlags Flags; // Build flags (see ImFontAtlasFlags_)
2361  ImTextureID TexID; // User data to refer to the texture once it has been uploaded to user's graphic systems. It is passed back to you during rendering via the ImDrawCmd structure.
2362  int TexDesiredWidth; // Texture width desired by user before Build(). Must be a power-of-two. If have many glyphs your graphics API have texture size restrictions you may want to increase texture width to decrease height.
2363  int TexGlyphPadding; // Padding between glyphs within texture in pixels. Defaults to 1. If your rendering method doesn't rely on bilinear filtering you may set this to 0.
2364 
2365  // [Internal]
2366  // NB: Access texture data via GetTexData*() calls! Which will setup a default font for you.
2367  unsigned char* TexPixelsAlpha8; // 1 component per pixel, each component is unsigned 8-bit. Total size = TexWidth * TexHeight
2368  unsigned int* TexPixelsRGBA32; // 4 component per pixel, each component is unsigned 8-bit. Total size = TexWidth * TexHeight * 4
2369  int TexWidth; // Texture width calculated during Build().
2370  int TexHeight; // Texture height calculated during Build().
2371  ImVec2 TexUvScale; // = (1.0f/TexWidth, 1.0f/TexHeight)
2372  ImVec2 TexUvWhitePixel; // Texture coordinates to a white pixel
2373  ImVector<ImFont*> Fonts; // Hold all the fonts returned by AddFont*. Fonts[0] is the default font upon calling ImGui::NewFrame(), use ImGui::PushFont()/PopFont() to change the current font.
2374  ImVector<ImFontAtlasCustomRect> CustomRects; // Rectangles for packing custom texture data into the atlas.
2375  ImVector<ImFontConfig> ConfigData; // Internal data
2376  int CustomRectIds[1]; // Identifiers of custom texture rectangle used by ImFontAtlas/ImDrawList
2377 
2378 #ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE_OBSOLETE_FUNCTIONS
2379  typedef ImFontAtlasCustomRect CustomRect; // OBSOLETED in 1.72+
2380  typedef ImFontGlyphRangesBuilder GlyphRangesBuilder; // OBSOLETED in 1.67+
2381 #endif
2382 };
2383 
2384 // Font runtime data and rendering
2385 // ImFontAtlas automatically loads a default embedded font for you when you call GetTexDataAsAlpha8() or GetTexDataAsRGBA32().
2386 struct ImFont
2387 {
2388  // Members: Hot ~20/24 bytes (for CalcTextSize)
2389  ImVector<float> IndexAdvanceX; // 12-16 // out // // Sparse. Glyphs->AdvanceX in a directly indexable way (cache-friendly for CalcTextSize functions which only this this info, and are often bottleneck in large UI).
2390  float FallbackAdvanceX; // 4 // out // = FallbackGlyph->AdvanceX
2391  float FontSize; // 4 // in // // Height of characters/line, set during loading (don't change after loading)
2392 
2393  // Members: Hot ~36/48 bytes (for CalcTextSize + render loop)
2394  ImVector<ImWchar> IndexLookup; // 12-16 // out // // Sparse. Index glyphs by Unicode code-point.
2395  ImVector<ImFontGlyph> Glyphs; // 12-16 // out // // All glyphs.
2396  const ImFontGlyph* FallbackGlyph; // 4-8 // out // = FindGlyph(FontFallbackChar)
2397  ImVec2 DisplayOffset; // 8 // in // = (0,0) // Offset font rendering by xx pixels
2398 
2399  // Members: Cold ~32/40 bytes
2400  ImFontAtlas* ContainerAtlas; // 4-8 // out // // What we has been loaded into
2401  const ImFontConfig* ConfigData; // 4-8 // in // // Pointer within ContainerAtlas->ConfigData
2402  short ConfigDataCount; // 2 // in // ~ 1 // Number of ImFontConfig involved in creating this font. Bigger than 1 when merging multiple font sources into one ImFont.
2403  ImWchar FallbackChar; // 2 // in // = '?' // Replacement character if a glyph isn't found. Only set via SetFallbackChar()
2404  ImWchar EllipsisChar; // 2 // out // = -1 // Character used for ellipsis rendering.
2405  bool DirtyLookupTables; // 1 // out //
2406  float Scale; // 4 // in // = 1.f // Base font scale, multiplied by the per-window font scale which you can adjust with SetWindowFontScale()
2407  float Ascent, Descent; // 4+4 // out // // Ascent: distance from top to bottom of e.g. 'A' [0..FontSize]
2408  int MetricsTotalSurface;// 4 // out // // Total surface in pixels to get an idea of the font rasterization/texture cost (not exact, we approximate the cost of padding between glyphs)
2409  ImU8 Used4kPagesMap[(IM_UNICODE_CODEPOINT_MAX+1)/4096/8]; // 2 bytes if ImWchar=ImWchar16, 34 bytes if ImWchar==ImWchar32. Store 1-bit for each block of 4K codepoints that has one active glyph. This is mainly used to facilitate iterations across all used codepoints.
2410 
2411  // Methods
2412  IMGUI_API ImFont();
2413  IMGUI_API ~ImFont();
2414  IMGUI_API const ImFontGlyph*FindGlyph(ImWchar c) const;
2415  IMGUI_API const ImFontGlyph*FindGlyphNoFallback(ImWchar c) const;
2416  float GetCharAdvance(ImWchar c) const { return ((int)c < IndexAdvanceX.Size) ? IndexAdvanceX[(int)c] : FallbackAdvanceX; }
2417  bool IsLoaded() const { return ContainerAtlas != NULL; }
2418  const char* GetDebugName() const { return ConfigData ? ConfigData->Name : "<unknown>"; }
2419 
2420  // 'max_width' stops rendering after a certain width (could be turned into a 2d size). FLT_MAX to disable.
2421  // 'wrap_width' enable automatic word-wrapping across multiple lines to fit into given width. 0.0f to disable.
2422  IMGUI_API ImVec2 CalcTextSizeA(float size, float max_width, float wrap_width, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end = NULL, const char** remaining = NULL) const; // utf8
2423  IMGUI_API const char* CalcWordWrapPositionA(float scale, const char* text, const char* text_end, float wrap_width) const;
2424  IMGUI_API void RenderChar(ImDrawList* draw_list, float size, ImVec2 pos, ImU32 col, ImWchar c) const;
2425  IMGUI_API void RenderText(ImDrawList* draw_list, float size, ImVec2 pos, ImU32 col, const ImVec4& clip_rect, const char* text_begin, const char* text_end, float wrap_width = 0.0f, bool cpu_fine_clip = false) const;
2426 
2427  // [Internal] Don't use!
2428  IMGUI_API void BuildLookupTable();
2429  IMGUI_API void ClearOutputData();
2430  IMGUI_API void GrowIndex(int new_size);
2431  IMGUI_API void AddGlyph(ImWchar c, float x0, float y0, float x1, float y1, float u0, float v0, float u1, float v1, float advance_x);
2432  IMGUI_API void AddRemapChar(ImWchar dst, ImWchar src, bool overwrite_dst = true); // Makes 'dst' character/glyph points to 'src' character/glyph. Currently needs to be called AFTER fonts have been built.
2433  IMGUI_API void SetGlyphVisible(ImWchar c, bool visible);
2434  IMGUI_API void SetFallbackChar(ImWchar c);
2435  IMGUI_API bool IsGlyphRangeUnused(unsigned int c_begin, unsigned int c_last);
2436 };
2437 
2438 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2439 // [BETA] Platform interface for multi-viewport support
2440 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2441 // (Optional) This is completely optional, for advanced users!
2442 // If you are new to Dear ImGui and trying to integrate it into your engine, you can probably ignore this for now.
2443 //
2444 // This feature allows you to seamlessly drag Dear ImGui windows outside of your application viewport.
2445 // This is achieved by creating new Platform/OS windows on the fly, and rendering into them.
2446 // Dear ImGui manages the viewport structures, and the back-end create and maintain one Platform/OS window for each of those viewports.
2447 //
2448 // See Glossary https://github.com/ocornut/imgui/wiki/Glossary for details about some of the terminology.
2449 // See Thread https://github.com/ocornut/imgui/issues/1542 for gifs, news and questions about this evolving feature.
2450 //
2451 // About the coordinates system:
2452 // - When multi-viewports are enabled, all Dear ImGui coordinates become absolute coordinates (same as OS coordinates!)
2453 // - So e.g. ImGui::SetNextWindowPos(ImVec2(0,0)) will position a window relative to your primary monitor!
2454 // - If you want to position windows relative to your main application viewport, use ImGui::GetMainViewport()->Pos as a base position.
2455 //
2456 // Steps to use multi-viewports in your application, when using a default back-end from the examples/ folder:
2457 // - Application: Enable feature with 'io.ConfigFlags |= ImGuiConfigFlags_ViewportsEnable'.
2458 // - Back-end: The back-end initialization will setup all necessary ImGuiPlatformIO's functions and update monitors info every frame.
2459 // - Application: In your main loop, call ImGui::UpdatePlatformWindows(), ImGui::RenderPlatformWindowsDefault() after EndFrame() or Render().
2460 // - Application: Fix absolute coordinates used in ImGui::SetWindowPos() or ImGui::SetNextWindowPos() calls.
2461 //
2462 // Steps to use multi-viewports in your application, when using a custom back-end:
2463 // - Important: THIS IS NOT EASY TO DO and comes with many subtleties not described here!
2464 // It's also an experimental feature, so some of the requirements may evolve.
2465 // Consider using default back-ends if you can. Either way, carefully follow and refer to examples/ back-ends for details.
2466 // - Application: Enable feature with 'io.ConfigFlags |= ImGuiConfigFlags_ViewportsEnable'.
2467 // - Back-end: Hook ImGuiPlatformIO's Platform_* and Renderer_* callbacks (see below).
2468 // Set 'io.BackendFlags |= ImGuiBackendFlags_PlatformHasViewports' and 'io.BackendFlags |= ImGuiBackendFlags_PlatformHasViewports'.
2469 // Update ImGuiPlatformIO's Monitors list every frame.
2470 // Update MousePos every frame, in absolute coordinates.
2471 // - Application: In your main loop, call ImGui::UpdatePlatformWindows(), ImGui::RenderPlatformWindowsDefault() after EndFrame() or Render().
2472 // You may skip calling RenderPlatformWindowsDefault() if its API is not convenient for your needs. Read comments below.
2473 // - Application: Fix absolute coordinates used in ImGui::SetWindowPos() or ImGui::SetNextWindowPos() calls.
2474 //
2475 // About ImGui::RenderPlatformWindowsDefault():
2476 // - This function is a mostly a _helper_ for the common-most cases, and to facilitate using default back-ends.
2477 // - You can check its simple source code to understand what it does.
2478 // It basically iterates secondary viewports and call 4 functions that are setup in ImGuiPlatformIO, if available:
2479 // Platform_RenderWindow(), Renderer_RenderWindow(), Platform_SwapBuffers(), Renderer_SwapBuffers()
2480 // Those functions pointers exists only for the benefit of RenderPlatformWindowsDefault().
2481 // - If you have very specific rendering needs (e.g. flipping multiple swap-chain simultaneously, unusual sync/threading issues, etc.),
2482 // you may be tempted to ignore RenderPlatformWindowsDefault() and write customized code to perform your renderingg.
2483 // You may decide to setup the platform_io's *RenderWindow and *SwapBuffers pointers and call your functions through those pointers,
2484 // or you may decide to never setup those pointers and call your code directly. They are a convenience, not an obligatory interface.
2485 //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2486 
2487 // (Optional) Access via ImGui::GetPlatformIO()
2488 struct ImGuiPlatformIO
2489 {
2490  //------------------------------------------------------------------
2491  // Input - Back-end interface/functions + Monitor List
2492  //------------------------------------------------------------------
2493 
2494  // (Optional) Platform functions (e.g. Win32, GLFW, SDL2)
2495  // For reference, the second column shows which function are generally calling the Platform Functions:
2496  // N = ImGui::NewFrame() ~ beginning of the dear imgui frame: read info from platform/OS windows (latest size/position)
2497  // F = ImGui::Begin(), ImGui::EndFrame() ~ during the dear imgui frame
2498  // U = ImGui::UpdatePlatformWindows() ~ after the dear imgui frame: create and update all platform/OS windows
2499  // R = ImGui::RenderPlatformWindowsDefault() ~ render
2500  // D = ImGui::DestroyPlatformWindows() ~ shutdown
2501  // The general idea is that NewFrame() we will read the current Platform/OS state, and UpdatePlatformWindows() will write to it.
2502  //
2503  // The functions are designed so we can mix and match 2 imgui_impl_xxxx files, one for the Platform (~window/input handling), one for Renderer.
2504  // Custom engine back-ends will often provide both Platform and Renderer interfaces and so may not need to use all functions.
2505  // Platform functions are typically called before their Renderer counterpart, apart from Destroy which are called the other way.
2506 
2507  // Platform function --------------------------------------------------- Called by -----
2508  void (*Platform_CreateWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // . . U . . // Create a new platform window for the given viewport
2509  void (*Platform_DestroyWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // N . U . D //
2510  void (*Platform_ShowWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // . . U . . // Newly created windows are initially hidden so SetWindowPos/Size/Title can be called on them before showing the window
2511  void (*Platform_SetWindowPos)(ImGuiViewport* vp, ImVec2 pos); // . . U . . // Set platform window position (given the upper-left corner of client area)
2512  ImVec2 (*Platform_GetWindowPos)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // N . . . . //
2513  void (*Platform_SetWindowSize)(ImGuiViewport* vp, ImVec2 size); // . . U . . // Set platform window client area size (ignoring OS decorations such as OS title bar etc.)
2514  ImVec2 (*Platform_GetWindowSize)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // N . . . . // Get platform window client area size
2515  void (*Platform_SetWindowFocus)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // N . . . . // Move window to front and set input focus
2516  bool (*Platform_GetWindowFocus)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // . . U . . //
2517  bool (*Platform_GetWindowMinimized)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // N . . . . // Get platform window minimized state. When minimized, we generally won't attempt to get/set size and contents will be culled more easily
2518  void (*Platform_SetWindowTitle)(ImGuiViewport* vp, const char* str); // . . U . . // Set platform window title (given an UTF-8 string)
2519  void (*Platform_SetWindowAlpha)(ImGuiViewport* vp, float alpha); // . . U . . // (Optional) Setup window transparency
2520  void (*Platform_UpdateWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // . . U . . // (Optional) Called by UpdatePlatformWindows(). Optional hook to allow the platform back-end from doing general book-keeping every frame.
2521  void (*Platform_RenderWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp, void* render_arg); // . . . R . // (Optional) Main rendering (platform side! This is often unused, or just setting a "current" context for OpenGL bindings). 'render_arg' is the value passed to RenderPlatformWindowsDefault().
2522  void (*Platform_SwapBuffers)(ImGuiViewport* vp, void* render_arg); // . . . R . // (Optional) Call Present/SwapBuffers (platform side! This is often unused!). 'render_arg' is the value passed to RenderPlatformWindowsDefault().
2523  float (*Platform_GetWindowDpiScale)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // N . . . . // (Optional) [BETA] FIXME-DPI: DPI handling: Return DPI scale for this viewport. 1.0f = 96 DPI.
2524  void (*Platform_OnChangedViewport)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // . F . . . // (Optional) [BETA] FIXME-DPI: DPI handling: Called during Begin() every time the viewport we are outputting into changes, so back-end has a chance to swap fonts to adjust style.
2525  void (*Platform_SetImeInputPos)(ImGuiViewport* vp, ImVec2 pos); // . F . . . // (Optional) Set IME (Input Method Editor, e.g. for Asian languages) input position, so text preview appears over the imgui input box. FIXME: The call timing of this is inconsistent because we want to support without multi-viewports.
2526  int (*Platform_CreateVkSurface)(ImGuiViewport* vp, ImU64 vk_inst, const void* vk_allocators, ImU64* out_vk_surface); // (Optional) For a Vulkan Renderer to call into Platform code (since the surface creation needs to tie them both).
2527 
2528  // (Optional) Renderer functions (e.g. DirectX, OpenGL, Vulkan)
2529  void (*Renderer_CreateWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // . . U . . // Create swap chain, frame buffers etc. (called after Platform_CreateWindow)
2530  void (*Renderer_DestroyWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp); // N . U . D // Destroy swap chain, frame buffers etc. (called before Platform_DestroyWindow)
2531  void (*Renderer_SetWindowSize)(ImGuiViewport* vp, ImVec2 size); // . . U . . // Resize swap chain, frame buffers etc. (called after Platform_SetWindowSize)
2532  void (*Renderer_RenderWindow)(ImGuiViewport* vp, void* render_arg); // . . . R . // (Optional) Clear framebuffer, setup render target, then render the viewport->DrawData. 'render_arg' is the value passed to RenderPlatformWindowsDefault().
2533  void (*Renderer_SwapBuffers)(ImGuiViewport* vp, void* render_arg); // . . . R . // (Optional) Call Present/SwapBuffers. 'render_arg' is the value passed to RenderPlatformWindowsDefault().
2534 
2535  // (Optional) Monitor list
2536  // - Updated by: app/back-end. Update every frame to dynamically support changing monitor or DPI configuration.
2537  // - Used by: dear imgui to query DPI info, clamp popups/tooltips within same monitor and not have them straddle monitors.
2538  ImVector<ImGuiPlatformMonitor> Monitors;
2539 
2540  //------------------------------------------------------------------
2541  // Output - List of viewports to render into platform windows
2542  //------------------------------------------------------------------
2543 
2544  // Viewports list (the list is updated by calling ImGui::EndFrame or ImGui::Render)
2545  // (in the future we will attempt to organize this feature to remove the need for a "main viewport")
2546  ImGuiViewport* MainViewport; // Guaranteed to be == Viewports[0]
2547  ImVector<ImGuiViewport*> Viewports; // Main viewports, followed by all secondary viewports.
2548  ImGuiPlatformIO() { memset(this, 0, sizeof(*this)); } // Zero clear
2549 };
2550 
2551 // (Optional) This is required when enabling multi-viewport. Represent the bounds of each connected monitor/display and their DPI.
2552 // We use this information for multiple DPI support + clamping the position of popups and tooltips so they don't straddle multiple monitors.
2553 struct ImGuiPlatformMonitor
2554 {
2555  ImVec2 MainPos, MainSize; // Coordinates of the area displayed on this monitor (Min = upper left, Max = bottom right)
2556  ImVec2 WorkPos, WorkSize; // (Optional) Coordinates without task bars / side bars / menu bars. imgui uses this to avoid positioning popups/tooltips inside this region.
2557  float DpiScale; // 1.0f = 96 DPI
2558  ImGuiPlatformMonitor() { MainPos = MainSize = WorkPos = WorkSize = ImVec2(0, 0); DpiScale = 1.0f; }
2559 };
2560 
2561 // Flags stored in ImGuiViewport::Flags, giving indications to the platform back-ends.
2562 enum ImGuiViewportFlags_
2563 {
2564  ImGuiViewportFlags_None = 0,
2565  ImGuiViewportFlags_NoDecoration = 1 << 0, // Platform Window: Disable platform decorations: title bar, borders, etc. (generally set all windows, but if ImGuiConfigFlags_ViewportsDecoration is set we only set this on popups/tooltips)
2566  ImGuiViewportFlags_NoTaskBarIcon = 1 << 1, // Platform Window: Disable platform task bar icon (generally set on popups/tooltips, or all windows if ImGuiConfigFlags_ViewportsNoTaskBarIcon is set)
2567  ImGuiViewportFlags_NoFocusOnAppearing = 1 << 2, // Platform Window: Don't take focus when created.
2568  ImGuiViewportFlags_NoFocusOnClick = 1 << 3, // Platform Window: Don't take focus when clicked on.
2569  ImGuiViewportFlags_NoInputs = 1 << 4, // Platform Window: Make mouse pass through so we can drag this window while peaking behind it.
2570  ImGuiViewportFlags_NoRendererClear = 1 << 5, // Platform Window: Renderer doesn't need to clear the framebuffer ahead (because we will fill it entirely).
2571  ImGuiViewportFlags_TopMost = 1 << 6, // Platform Window: Display on top (for tooltips only).
2572  ImGuiViewportFlags_Minimized = 1 << 7, // Platform Window: Window is minimized, can skip render. When minimized we tend to avoid using the viewport pos/size for clipping window or testing if they are contained in the viewport.
2573  ImGuiViewportFlags_NoAutoMerge = 1 << 8, // Platform Window: Avoid merging this window into another host window. This can only be set via ImGuiWindowClass viewport flags override (because we need to now ahead if we are going to create a viewport in the first place!).
2574  ImGuiViewportFlags_CanHostOtherWindows = 1 << 9 // Main viewport: can host multiple imgui windows (secondary viewports are associated to a single window).
2575 };
2576 
2577 // The viewports created and managed by Dear ImGui. The role of the platform back-end is to create the platform/OS windows corresponding to each viewport.
2578 // - Main Area = entire viewport.
2579 // - Work Area = entire viewport minus sections optionally used by menu bars, status bars. Some positioning code will prefer to use this. Window are also trying to stay within this area.
2580 struct ImGuiViewport
2581 {
2582  ImGuiID ID; // Unique identifier for the viewport
2583  ImGuiViewportFlags Flags; // See ImGuiViewportFlags_
2584  ImVec2 Pos; // Main Area: Position of the viewport (the imgui coordinates are the same as OS desktop/native coordinates)
2585  ImVec2 Size; // Main Area: Size of the viewport.
2586  ImVec2 WorkOffsetMin; // Work Area: Offset from Pos to top-left corner of Work Area. Generally (0,0) or (0,+main_menu_bar_height). Work Area is Full Area but without menu-bars/status-bars (so WorkArea always fit inside Pos/Size!)
2587  ImVec2 WorkOffsetMax; // Work Area: Offset from Pos+Size to bottom-right corner of Work Area. Generally (0,0) or (0,-status_bar_height).
2588  float DpiScale; // 1.0f = 96 DPI = No extra scale.
2589  ImDrawData* DrawData; // The ImDrawData corresponding to this viewport. Valid after Render() and until the next call to NewFrame().
2590  ImGuiID ParentViewportId; // (Advanced) 0: no parent. Instruct the platform back-end to setup a parent/child relationship between platform windows.
2591 
2592  // Our design separate the Renderer and Platform back-ends to facilitate combining default back-ends with each others.
2593  // When our create your own back-end for a custom engine, it is possible that both Renderer and Platform will be handled
2594  // by the same system and you may not need to use all the UserData/Handle fields.
2595  // The library never uses those fields, they are merely storage to facilitate back-end implementation.
2596  void* RendererUserData; // void* to hold custom data structure for the renderer (e.g. swap chain, framebuffers etc.). generally set by your Renderer_CreateWindow function.
2597  void* PlatformUserData; // void* to hold custom data structure for the OS / platform (e.g. windowing info, render context). generally set by your Platform_CreateWindow function.
2598  void* PlatformHandle; // void* for FindViewportByPlatformHandle(). (e.g. suggested to use natural platform handle such as HWND, GLFWWindow*, SDL_Window*)
2599  void* PlatformHandleRaw; // void* to hold lower-level, platform-native window handle (e.g. the HWND) when using an abstraction layer like GLFW or SDL (where PlatformHandle would be a SDL_Window*)
2600  bool PlatformRequestMove; // Platform window requested move (e.g. window was moved by the OS / host window manager, authoritative position will be OS window position)
2601  bool PlatformRequestResize; // Platform window requested resize (e.g. window was resized by the OS / host window manager, authoritative size will be OS window size)
2602  bool PlatformRequestClose; // Platform window requested closure (e.g. window was moved by the OS / host window manager, e.g. pressing ALT-F4)
2603 
2604  ImGuiViewport() { ID = 0; Flags = 0; DpiScale = 0.0f; DrawData = NULL; ParentViewportId = 0; RendererUserData = PlatformUserData = PlatformHandle = PlatformHandleRaw = NULL; PlatformRequestMove = PlatformRequestResize = PlatformRequestClose = false; }
2605  ~ImGuiViewport() { IM_ASSERT(PlatformUserData == NULL && RendererUserData == NULL); }
2606 
2607  // Access work-area rectangle
2608  ImVec2 GetWorkPos() { return ImVec2(Pos.x + WorkOffsetMin.x, Pos.y + WorkOffsetMin.y); }
2609  ImVec2 GetWorkSize() { return ImVec2(Size.x - WorkOffsetMin.x + WorkOffsetMax.x, Size.y - WorkOffsetMin.y + WorkOffsetMax.y); } // This not clamped
2610 };
2611 
2612 #if defined(__clang__)
2613 #pragma clang diagnostic pop
2614 #elif defined(__GNUC__)
2615 #pragma GCC diagnostic pop
2616 #endif
2617 
2618 // Include imgui_user.h at the end of imgui.h (convenient for user to only explicitly include vanilla imgui.h)
2619 #ifdef IMGUI_INCLUDE_IMGUI_USER_H
2620 #include "imgui_user.h"
2621 #endif
2622 
2623 #endif // #ifndef IMGUI_DISABLE
